author: ralexstokes
content:
hey all! wanted to leave a summary of key decisions from last ACDC (https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1812) to facilitate scoping decisions for Glamsterdam
* FOCIL
  * interest to schedule for Heka/Bogota, core devs undecided if we should write as CFI or SFI
    * CFI: follows established processes, not as strong a signal as SFI
    * SFI: strong signal (reflecting community demand), but would be getting ahead of ourselves in terms of Heka/Bogota scoping as we have not started headliner selection for this fork yet
    * will make final call on next ACDC
      * client teams, please come prepared with a team preference on how to scope FOCIL in Heka / Bogota
* 7688
  * need to do due diligence on complexity; demand for feature exists for Glam, but could imply larger than expected implementation cost, along with more testing/review and potential audits
  * will make final call on next ACDC
* 8045
  * CFI, some questions around complexity raised but due diligence has been done here; possibility to not SFI if cost becomes higher than currently expected
* 8061
  * see summary for 8080
* 8062
  * DFI
* 8071
  * DFI, in favor of 8080/8061
* 8080
  * lean CFI, but want to better understand if we should do 8061 instead
  * main thing here is deeper security review of changing weak subjectivity periods
  * will make final call on 8080/8061 route on next call

author: zsfelfoldi
content:
Not sure where is the best place to advertise this but it might be relevant for EIP inclusion discussions on this week's ACDE. Now I have a WIP EELS implementation of EIP-7745 which might answer some open questions. It needs more work, still a draft, but I think it already shows how this thing can be realized in a not extremely complicated way and also defines all corner cases exactly. I also want to do a quick explanatory write-up soon about how initialization, wire protocol extension, database storage, rollback handling and things like that can be realized in practice.
https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/pull/1832
The EIP itself has also been updated, now it's consistent with the EELS code and also cleaned up the terminology a bit.

author: 0xunclebill
content: imo we shouldn't ship 6 second slots without FOCIL. bandwidth requirements for local block building post BPO forks and post 6 second slots increases significantly which effectively kills local block building. This gives centralized block builders even more control over transaction inclusion. that seems problematic to me

author: greystroke
content: True, but as I recall SSS also had near unanimous client support for HegotÃ¡ at that time and it definitely the more  user UX facing upgrade. I think there will be a lot of unhappy stakeholders from users to L2s if SSS gets pushed when it was signaled for immediately after Glamsterdam.

author: barnabasbusa
content: One significant difference is that SSS doesn't have an active champion right now, while FOCIL does.

author: tersec
content: "user-facing", also, is an somewhat arbitrary metric. It's a question of how to market the EIPs, of how to promote them. 6 second slots is somewhat more obvious, yes, but FOCIL can be said to be "user-facing" in much the same way. Furthermore, "user-facing" on its own isn't even necessarily the primary virtue of an EIP; the question is what value they provide to Ethereum as a system (which, yes, includes its stakeholders, and that does include users), not only what basically are obvious-front-end-visible EIPs. I mention this because multiple hardfork cycles have seen valorization of "user-facing EIPs" (or similar language) and it's somewhat circular each time
